conclusion: To determine if objects A and B have the same acceleration at time t1, analyze the velocity-time graphs for both objects.
Object A's velocity is represented by the red straight line from origin to point (t2, v0) and then back down to (t4, 0).
Object B's velocity is represented by the curved line that starts at the origin, gradually decreases in slope, and eventually reaches v0 near t4.
Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, which equals the slope of the velocity-time graph at a given point.
Object A follows a straight line from (0,0) to (t2, v0), and the slope of this line is constant: a_A = v0 / t2.
The constant acceleration for Object A throughout the interval [0, t2], including at time t1, is a_A = v0 / t2.
Object B follows a curved path from the origin, and the acceleration at t1 is the slope of the tangent to this curve at t1.
The curve for Object B is concave down at t1, meaning its slope is decreasing with time.
The slope at t1 for Object B appears to be less steep than the constant slope of Object A's line.
Object A has a constant positive slope (acceleration), while Object B's curve has a gentler slope at t1 than Object A's straight line.

No, the two objects do not have the same acceleration at time t1. Object A has a greater acceleration than Object B at time t1, as evidenced by the steeper slope of its velocity-time graph at that point.
